text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on February 19 in history.
1405 - Timur Lenk, also known as Tamerlane died while on his way to conquer China. He had already subdued lands stretching from Mongolia to the Mediterranean.
1408 - In England, the Northumberland Rebellion ended when Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland, was defeated by Henry IV at the battle of Bramham Moor.
1743 - Luigi Boccherini, Italian composer and cellist, born in Lucca. He composed several hundred chamber pieces and over 20 symphonies.
1800 - Napoleon Bonaparte established himself as First Consul in France.
1837 - Georg Buechner, German playwright and poet, died. A pioneer of Expressionist theatre, his best known works are "Dantons Tod" and "Woyzeck".
1843 - Adelina Patti, Italian soprano, born in Spain. Highest paid soprano of her day, she made her first recordings when she was past 60.
1878 - The phonograph, invented by Thomas Edison, was patented on this day by him. He secured patent No. 200,521.
1897 - Mrs Hoodless founded the first "Women's Institute" at Stoney Creek in Ontario, Canada.
1911 - Merle Oberon, film actress, born in Tasmania. Best known for her role of Cathy Linton in "Wuthering Heights".
1915 - In World War One, a combined British and French fleet attacked the Dardanelles.
1917 - Carson McCullers, U.S. novelist, born; she was best known for her "The Heart is a Lonely Hunter".
1918 - In Russia, a decree abolishing all private ownership of land, water and natural resources was issued by the Soviet Central Executive Committee.
1924 - Lee Marvin, U.S. film actor, born. He won an Oscar for his role in "Cat Ballou".
1941 - Hamilton Harty, Irish composer and conductor, died. He composed an "Irish Symphony" and conducted the Halle Orchestra in Manchester. (1920-1933). Best known for his conducting of Berlioz.
1942 - In World war Two, Japanese aircraft bombed Port Darwin, Australia.
1945 - The U.S. Fifth Fleet launched the invasion of Iwo Jima against the Japanese. The island was eventually taken on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 U.S. killed.
1951 - Andre Gide, French novelist, died. Awarded the Nobel Prize for literature in 1947, his literary reputation was gained for his analysis of moral conflicts.
1952 - Norwegian author Knut Hamsun (Pedersen), died. Despite no formal education, he won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1920 and was famed for his "Growth of the Soil" and "Hunger".
1959 - The Prime Ministers of Britain, Turkey and Greece signed an agreement in London for the independence of Cyprus.
1976 - Iceland broke off diplomatic relations with Britain after the two countries failed to agree over fishing rights in disputed waters. The dispute became known as the Cod War.
1982 - In Northern Ireland, receivers were appointed to manage the affairs of the De Lorean car company.
1990 - The Liberal Democrat Party in Japan won the general election under Toshiki Kaifu.
1994 - Fire bombs damaged six London stores; the IRA claimed responsiblility.
